'''Zachary Lane Bryan''' (born April 2, 1996) is an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter from [[Oologah, Oklahoma]].

After two self-produced studio albums—''[[DeAnn]]'' (2019) and ''[[Elisabeth (Zach Bryan album)|Elisabeth]]'' (2020)—he signed with [[Warner Records]] to release his third album and [[major label]] debut, ''[[American Heartbreak]]'' (2022), which peaked at number five on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and was led by the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]-top ten single, "[[Something in the Orange]]". His [[Zach Bryan (album)|self-titled fourth album]] (2023) debuted atop the ''Billboard'' 200, while its lead single, "[[I Remember Everything (Zach Bryan song)|I Remember Everything]]" (featuring [[Kacey Musgraves]]), peaked atop the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, [[Hot Country Songs]], and [[Hot Rock & Alternative Songs]] charts simultaneously, also earning him a [[Grammy Award for Best Country Duo/Group Performance]]. His fifth studio album, ''[[The Great American Bar Scene]]'' (2024), peaked at number two on the ''Billboard'' 200.

Throughout his career, he has been recognized with an [[Academy of Country Music Award for New Male Artist of the Year]] and four [[Billboard Music Awards|''Billboard'' Music Awards]]. Bryan has sold over 30 million albums and singles, according to the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA).

==Early life==
Bryan was born in [[Okinawa Prefecture|Okinawa]], [[Japan]],<ref name="KOCO 5 News">{{cite news| url= https://www.koco.com/article/5-things-you-didnt-know-about-zach-bryan-okc-concert/60829002| work=KOCO 5 News| first=Jonathan| last=Greco | title= WATCH: 5 things you didn't know about Zach Bryan according to his dad | date=May 17, 2024}}</ref> but grew up in [[Oologah, Oklahoma]].<ref name="opry">{{Cite web|title=Zach Byran - Grand Ole Opry|url=https://www.opry.com/artists/zach-bryan/|access-date=May 9, 2021|website=The Grand Ole Opry|language=en}}</ref> He is the son of Dewayne Bryan and Annette DeAnn (''née'' Mullen) Bryan, and has a sister, Mackenzie.<ref name="obituary">{{Cite web|title=Obituary for Annette DeAnn (Mullen) Bryan|url=https://www.lehmanfuneralhome.net/obituary/Annette-Bryan|access-date=May 9, 2021|website=Lehman Funeral Home|language=en}}</ref> He started writing songs at the age of 14.<ref name="BoxingDay" />

Continuing a family tradition, Bryan was an active-duty member of the [[United States Navy]] for seven years, enlisting at the age of 17.<ref name="BoxingDay">{{cite web |last=Moore |first=Addie |date=December 26, 2022 |title=Zach Bryan: Everything Die-Hard Fans Should Know About Country's Newest Headliner |url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/zach-bryan/ |access-date=January 17, 2023 |website=Open Country}}</ref> Bryan attained the rate/rating of [[Aviation Ordnanceman]] Second Class (AO2).<ref>{{cite AV media|time=0:30 |date=  |title= Ship2Shore with Aviation Ordnanceman 2nd Class Zach Bryan|people=LT Ian McConnaughey|type= Youtube Video |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rns_E0X4hs8|access-date= September 9, 2023|publisher= Navy Office of Community Outreach (NAVCO)}}</ref>  He used his spare time while in the Navy to write music for his enjoyment.<ref name="study">{{cite news| url=https://studybreaks.com/culture/music/zach-bryan/| work=Study Breaks | first=Nora | last=Markey| title=Zach Bryan Brings Authenticity And Soul To The World Of Country | date=June 17, 2020 |access-date=May 9, 2021}}</ref> He finished his service in the Navy in 2021 at the age of 25.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://holler.country/news/general/zach-bryan-all-the-big-questions-asked-and-answered/ |title=Zach Bryan: All the Big Questions Asked & Answered |date=May 25, 2023 |website=holler.country |first=Maxim |last=Mower |access-date=May 17, 2024}}</ref>

==Career==
=== 2017–2019: Beginnings on YouTube ===
Bryan started uploading his music to [[YouTube]] in 2017, with his friends recording him performing using his iPhone. Bryan's first song he uploaded to YouTube was the single "God Speed" which ended up being a track on his debut album.<ref>{{Citation |title=Zach Bryan- God Speed | date=March 11, 2018 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ycuVOznZmV0 |access-date=January 19, 2024 |language=en}}</ref> Many of the songs Bryan would upload to his YouTube were written and recorded by him while serving in the Navy.<ref>{{Cite web |date=October 31, 2023 |title=Zach Bryan Calls His Beginning Recordings Sh*tty, Says He 'Never Envisioned Being A Musician' While In The Navy |url=https://countrychord.com/watch-zach-bryan-calls-his-beginning-recordings-shtty-says-he-never-envisioned-being-a-musician-while-in-the-navy/ |website=Country Chord |first=Aidan |last=Callahan |access-date=January 19, 2024 |language=en-US}}</ref>

Bryan uploaded 16 songs of varying popularity onto his YouTube before "[[Heading South (song)|Heading South]]" went viral.<ref name="study" /> The song was recorded outside his Navy barracks.<ref>{{Cite web |title=About Zach |url=https://www.zachbryan.com/about-zach |access-date=January 13, 2024 |website=www.zachbryan.com}}</ref>

=== 2019–2020: ''DeAnn'' and ''Elisabeth'' ===
His debut album, ''[[DeAnn]]'', was dedicated to his late mother and released on August 24, 2019. It was written in two months and recorded with his friends in a Florida [[Airbnb]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Stories of Zach Bryan's debut album, 'DeAnn'|url=https://stonyjammer.com/interviews/zachbryan |access-date=May 9, 2021|website=Stony Jammer|date=September 13, 2019 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="study" /> The album consisted of 12 tracks, many of which had been previously uploaded to his YouTube.

Bryan's first public concert was in [[Medford, Oregon]] in October 2019.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Reesman |first=Bryan |date=November 7, 2023 |title=Who Is Zach Bryan, and How Did He Shoot to Fame? |url=https://americansongwriter.com/who-is-zach-bryan-and-how-did-he-shoot-to-fame/ |access-date=January 19, 2024 |website=American Songwriter |language=en-US}}</ref> He has since made his [[Ryman Auditorium|Ryman]] debut, among other noteworthy appearances.

A second album, ''[[Elisabeth (Zach Bryan album)|Elisabeth]]'', was released on May 8, 2020. He recorded the album in a repurposed barn behind his home in Washington. The album is named after Bryan's ex-wife Rose 'Elisabeth' Madden.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Robinson |first=Ellie |title=10 Things You Need To Know About Modern-Day Country Icon Zach Bryan |url=https://themusic.com.au/features/10-things-you-need-to-know-about-modern-day-country-icon-zach-bryan/7tdM4OPi5eQ/30-08-23 |access-date=January 19, 2024 |website=themusic.com.au |language=en}}</ref> The album contains 19 tracks including the tracks "Heading South" and "Revival".

Zach Bryan released his first EP ''Quiet, Heavy Dreams'' on November 27, 2020.<ref name="MelodicMag"/>

=== 2021–2022: ''American Heartbreak'' and "Something In The Orange" ===
On April 10, 2021, Bryan made his [[Grand Ole Opry]] debut. He later signed a deal with [[Warner Records]] to release his music.<ref name="Tennessean">{{cite news| url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2021/04/09/zach-bryan-makes-grand-ole-opry-debut-how-to-watch/7130030002/| work=The Tennessean | first=Matthew | last=Leimkuehler | title=Fast-rising country artist Zach Bryan makes his Opry debut this weekend | date=April 9, 2021}}</ref>

[[File:Zach Bryan Navy.png|thumb|Bryan while in the Navy, 2021]]
On October 14, 2021, Bryan announced that the U.S. Navy [[Military discharge|honorably discharged]] after eight years of service to pursue his career in music just ahead of his nationwide Fall 2021 "Ain't For Tamin' Tour".<ref>{{Cite web|last=Young|first=Casey|date=October 14, 2021|title=Zach Bryan Honorably Discharged From Active-Duty Service In The U.S. Navy To Pursue Music Full Time|url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2021/10/14/zach-bryan-honorably-discharged-from-active-duty-service-in-the-u-s-navy-to-pursue-music-full-time/|website=Whiskey Riff}}</ref> He said, "If it was my decision, I would never get out of the world's greatest Navy, but here I am and they kindly honorably discharged me to go play some music."<ref name="BoxingDay" />

On January 25, 2022, Bryan announced that he would release his major-label debut, a triple album, ''[[American Heartbreak]]'', on May 20, 2022.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Young|first=Casey|date=January 25, 2022|title=Zach Bryan Announces Debut Studio Album, ''American Heartbreak'', Coming This Spring|url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2022/01/25/zach-bryan-announces-new-album-american-heartbreak-will-drop-may-20th/|website=Whiskey Riff}}</ref> On April 22, 2022, Bryan released the hit single "[[Something in the Orange]]", which became a mainstream hit and is regarded as one of Bryan's most recognizable and identifiable songs.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Horowitz |first=Steven J. |date=November 29, 2023 |title=How Zach Bryan's 'Something in the Orange' Struck a Chord With Listeners — And Why It's Still Ringing |url=https://variety.com/2023/music/news/zach-bryan-something-in-the-orange-ryan-hadlock-1235811782/ |access-date=January 19, 2024 |website=Variety |language=en-US}}</ref> The song was Bryan's breakthrough onto the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] debuting at position 55 on May 7, 2022, and peaking at 10.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last1=Werthman |first1=Jason Lipshutz, Melinda Newman, Jessica Nicholson, Andrew Unterberger, Christine |last2=Lipshutz |first2=Jason |last3=Newman |first3=Melinda |last4=Nicholson |first4=Jessica |last5=Unterberger |first5=Andrew |last6=Werthman |first6=Christine |date=January 18, 2023 |title=Five Burning Questions: Zach Bryan Finally Reaches the Hot 100's Top 10 With 'Something in the Orange' |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/chart-beat/zach-bryan-something-in-the-orange-top-10-five-burning-questions-1235200789/ |access-date=January 19, 2024 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref>

''American Heartbreak'' debuted at number five on the U.S. [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] with over 70,000 [[album-equivalent unit]]s, marking the biggest first week for a country album in 2022.<ref name="AH BB200">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/chart-beat/harry-styles-harrys-house-number-one-billboard-200-chart-1235078807/|title=Harry Styles' 'Harry's House' Debuts at No. 1 on Billboard 200 With Half-Million-Plus First Week in U.S.|magazine=Billboard |last=Caulfield|first=Keith|date=May 29, 2022|access-date=May 30, 2022}}</ref> The album consisted of 34 tracks including "Something in the Orange – Z&E's Version" a more raw and acoustic version of the hit song.

On July 15, 2022, Bryan released his second EP, ''[[Summertime Blues (EP)|Summertime Blues]]'', which featured collaborator [[Charles Wesley Godwin|Charles Wesley Goodwin]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hollabaugh |first=Lorie |date=July 14, 2022 |title=Zach Bryan Embraces The Season With New EP 'Summertime Blues' |url=https://musicrow.com/2022/07/zach-bryan-embraces-the-season-with-new-ep-summertime-blues/ |access-date=January 12, 2024 |website=MusicRow.com |language=en-US}}</ref> The EP contained nine tracks including the charting song of "Oklahoma Smokeshow" which peaked at number 75.

On September 8, 2022, Bryan released the single "Burn, Burn, Burn" followed by the single "Starved" on October 10. These were followed by the two singles "Fifth of May" and "The Greatest Day of My Life" on November 11, 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |last=MUSICVIDEOS· |first=Casey Young·COUNTRY |date=September 8, 2022 |title=Zach Bryan Releases Official Studio Version Of "Burn, Burn, Burn" |url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2022/09/08/zach-bryan-releases-official-studio-version-of-burn-burn-burn/ |access-date=January 13, 2024 |website=Whiskey Riff |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Young |first=Casey |date=October 10, 2022 |title=Zach Bryan Drops Surprise Full-Length Live Recording Of Unreleased Song "Starved" |url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2022/10/10/zach-bryan-drops-full-length-live-recording-of-unreleased-song-starved/ |access-date=November 15, 2023 |website=Whiskey Riff |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Cox |first=Brady |date=November 11, 2022 |title=Zach Bryan Drops New Single "Fifth Of May," Releases "The Greatest Day Of My Life" On Streaming Platforms |url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2022/11/11/zach-bryan-drops-new-single-fifth-of-may-releases-the-greatest-day-of-my-life-on-streaming-platforms/ |access-date=November 15, 2023 |website=Whiskey Riff |language=en-US}}</ref>

On December 25, 2022, he released a live album called ''[[All My Homies Hate Ticketmaster (Live from Red Rocks)]]'', recorded at [[Red Rocks Amphitheatre]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Willman |first=Chris |date=December 25, 2022 |title=Zach Bryan Drops Live Album, Titled ''All My Homies Hate Ticketmaster'', While Vowing to Find Ticketing Work-Around for 2023 Tour |url=https://variety.com/2022/music/news/zach-bryan-live-album-all-my-homies-hate-ticketmaster-statement-ticket-costs-tour-1235472757/ |access-date=January 12, 2023 |website=Variety |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=December 25, 2022 |title=Zach Bryan Shares Christmas Message About Concert Ticket Prices, Drops Surprise Live Album |url=https://www.stereogum.com/2209169/zach-bryan-concert-ticket-prices-message-live-album/news/ |access-date=January 12, 2023 |website=Stereogum |language=en}}</ref>

Bryan's single "Something In The Orange" was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Solo Performance|Best Country Solo Performance]] at the [[65th Annual Grammy Awards]] marking Bryan's first career [[Grammy Awards]] nomination.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Zach Bryan's 'Something in the Orange' Nominated For 2023 Grammy Awards {{!}} Holler |url=https://holler.country/news/general/zach-bryan-something-in-the-orange-nominated-for-2023-grammy-award |access-date=January 12, 2024 |website=holler.country |language=en}}</ref>

=== 2023–present: ''Zach Bryan'' and ''The Great American Bar Scene'' ===
[[File:Zach Bryan Melbourne.jpg|thumb|Bryan performing at [[Flemington Racecourse]], [[Melbourne]], Australia in 2023|left|268x268px]]On January 27, 2023, Bryan collaborated with [[Maggie Rogers]] and released "[[Dawns (song)|Dawns]]", his first single of the year.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Freeman |first=Jon |date=January 27, 2023 |title=Zach Bryan Drops New Song 'Dawns' With Maggie Rogers |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/zach-bryan-maggie-rogers-dawns-1234669281/amp/ |access-date=November 15, 2023 |website=RollingStone |language=en-US}}</ref> The single reached a peak of 42 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100.<ref name="billboard.com">{{Cite magazine |title=Zach Bryan {{!}} Biography, Music & News |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/zach-bryan/ |access-date=January 13, 2024 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref>

In May 2023, Bryan received the [[Academy of Country Music Award for New Male Artist of the Year]].

On August 25, 2023, Bryan released his [[Zach Bryan (album)|self-titled]] fourth album.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://musicrow.com/2023/08/zach-bryan-to-release-self-titled-album-this-friday |title=Zach Bryan to Release Self-Titled Album This Friday |author=Liza Anderson |website=Music Row |date=August 21, 2023 |access-date=August 25, 2023}}</ref> It debuted at number one on the ''Billboard'' 200.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/billboard-200/2023-09-09/ | title=Billboard 200™ | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] }}</ref> The album also contained Bryan's first number one single, "[[I Remember Everything (Zach Bryan song)|I Remember Everything]]", featuring [[Kacey Musgraves]], which debuted on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 at the top spot.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Trust |first=Gary |date=September 5, 2023 |title=Zach Bryan & Kacey Musgraves' 'I Remember Everything' Debuts at No. 1 on Billboard Hot 100 |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/chart-beat/zach-bryan-i-remember-everything-hot-100-number-one-debut-1235405939/ |access-date=January 12, 2024 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref> All sixteen tracks of the album charted on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 with "I Remember Everything", "Hey Driver" (featuring [[The War and Treaty]]), "Spotless" (featuring [[The Lumineers]]), "East Side of Sorrow", and "Tourniquet" all appearing in the top 20.<ref name="billboard.com"/>

On September 22, 2023, he released his third EP, ''[[Boys of Faith]]'', which included songs featuring fellow artists [[Noah Kahan]] and [[Bon Iver]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/zach-bryan-boys-of-faith-ep-bon-iver-noah-kahan-1234829440/amp/ |title=Zach Bryan Fuels Hot Streak With 'Boys of Faith' EP, Enlisting Bon Iver, Noah Kahan |author=Charisma Madarang |website=RollingStone |date=September 22, 2023 |access-date=September 22, 2023}}</ref> All five tracks on the EP charted on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 with "Sarah's Place" featuring Kahan peaking at 14.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=tolsen |date=January 2, 2013 |title=Billboard Hot 100™ |url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-100/ |access-date=January 13, 2024 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref>

Bryan was named ''[[Billboard charts|Billboard]]''{{'}}s top new artist of 2023 for his increased popularity through the year, such as his first appearance at the top of both the ''Billboard'' 200 and ''Billboard'' Hot 100.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Caulfield |first=Keith |date=November 21, 2023 |title=Zach Bryan Is Billboard's Top New Artist of 2023 |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/chart-beat/zach-bryan-billboard-top-new-artist-2023-1235491480/ |access-date=January 12, 2024 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref>

At the [[66th Annual Grammy Awards]] Bryan was nominated for three categories. His self-titled fourth album was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]]. "I Remember Everything" featuring Musgraves was nominated for the [[Grammy Award for Best Country Song|Best Country Song]]. The song was also nominated and won the [[Grammy Award for Best Country Duo/Group Performance|Best Country Duo/Group Performance]] marking Bryan's first Grammy award win of his career.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Oklahoma country music star Zach Bryan is officially a Grammy Award winner |url=https://www.oklahoman.com/story/entertainment/2024/02/04/oklahomas-zach-bryan-wins-grammy-award-with-kacey-musgraves/72475001007/ |access-date=February 5, 2024 |website=The Oklahoman |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=November 13, 2023 |title=Oklahoma country musician Zach Bryan nominated for 3 Grammys |url=https://www.kosu.org/music/2023-11-13/oklahoma-country-musician-zach-bryan-nominated-for-3-grammys |access-date=January 12, 2024 |website=KOSU |language=en}}</ref>

In early 2024 Bryan began teasing and announcing his fifth studio album titled ''[[The Great American Bar Scene]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Varvaris |first=Mary |title=New Zach Bryan Album Confirmed |url=https://countrytown.com/news/new-zach-bryan-album-confirmed/mbknjYyPjrE/03-05-24 |access-date=2024-05-25 |website=Countrytown |language=en}}</ref> On May 24, 2024, Bryan released the lead single from the album, "[[Pink Skies]]".<ref>{{Cite web |title=Zach Bryan to Release Long-Awaited New Single, 'Pink Skies (Eulogy)' {{!}} Holler |url=https://holler.country/news/breaking/zach-bryan-to-release-long-awaited-new-single-pink-skies-eulogy |access-date=2024-05-21 |website=holler.country |language=en}}</ref> The single would debut at number 6 on the Billboard Hot 100, becoming the second highest charting single of his career up until this point.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last1=Werthman |first1=Eric Renner Brown, Kyle Denis, Melinda Newman, Andrew Unterberger, Christine |last2=Brown |first2=Eric Renner |last3=Denis |first3=Kyle |last4=Newman |first4=Melinda |last5=Unterberger |first5=Andrew |last6=Werthman |first6=Christine |date=2024-06-04 |title=How Meaningful Is Zach Bryan's 'Pink Skies' Top 10 Debut for His Career? |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/chart-beat/zach-bryan-pink-skies-chart-debut-five-burning-questions-1235700606/ |access-date=2024-07-07 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref> Bryan released the second single from the album titled "Purple Gas" which featured Noeline Hofmann, on June 7.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Hudak |first=Joseph |date=2024-06-07 |title=Noeline Hofmann's Song 'Purple Gas' Caught the Ear of Zach Bryan. They Just Released It as a Duet |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/zach-bryan-noeline-hofmann-purple-gas-song-1235034363/ |access-date=2024-07-07 |magazine=Rolling Stone |language=en-US}}</ref> The album was released on July 4, 2024. It contains 19 tracks including songs featuring artists Noeline Hofmann, [[John Moreland]], [[John Mayer]], and [[Bruce Springsteen]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Aniftos |first=Rania |date=2024-07-04 |title=Zach Bryan's 'Great American Bar Scene' Is Here: Stream It Now |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/zach-bryan-great-american-bar-scene-stream-1235724905/ |access-date=2024-07-04 |magazine=Billboard}}</ref>

==Personal life==
In July 2020, Bryan married Rose Madden; the pair dissolved their marriage in 2021.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nardino|first1=Meredith |title=Singer Zach Bryan's Dating History: From Ex-Wife to Barstool Fling |url=https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/zach-bryans-dating-history-meet-his-ex-wife-girlfriends |work=[[Us Weekly]]|language=en|date=September 13, 2023}}</ref> In July 2023, Bryan started dating Brianna LaPaglia, a podcaster with [[Barstool Sports]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=DeSantis |first1=Rachel |title=Brianna Chickenfry Says Zach Bryan Slid Into Her DMs — and They 'Got to Know Each Other' on 18-Hour Road Trip |url=https://people.com/brianna-chickenfry-zach-bryan-got-to-know-each-other-18-hour-road-trip-7570133|magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]] |access-date=August 7, 2023 |language=en|date=August 4, 2023}}</ref>

On September 7, 2023, he was arrested by the [[Oklahoma Highway Patrol]] for obstruction in [[Vinita, Oklahoma]], and released on bail.<ref>{{cite web|title=Country music star Zach Bryan arrested in Oklahoma amid chart-topping success and recent award nominations|date=September 7, 2023 |url=https://okcfox.com/news/local/country-music-star-zach-bryan-arrested-in-vinita-cma-award-oklahoma-jail-craig-county-arrest-police-something-in-the-orange-spotless-investigation-booked-obstruction|publisher=KOKH}}</ref><ref name="ok_arrest">{{cite news |title=Country star Zach Bryan arrested in Oklahoma: Police report sheds light on circumstances surrounding the traffic stop|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/country-star-zach-bryan-arrested-police/story?id=103016994|access-date=September 8, 2023 |work=ABC News |language=en}}</ref>

In September 2024, Bryan was criticized for posting on [[Twitter]] that "[[Kanye]] [is better than] [[Taylor Swift|Taylor]]."<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-09-19 |title=Zach Bryan apologizes to Swifties for drunkenly posting 'Kanye > Taylor,' deactivates his X account |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/pop-culture/pop-culture-news/zach-bryan-apologizes-swifties-drunkenly-posting-kanye-taylor-deactiva-rcna171884 |access-date=2024-09-20 |website=NBC News |language=en}}</ref> He later apologized on [[Instagram]], saying he was drunk at the time, and deactivated his account on Twitter.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Willman |first=Chris |date=2024-09-19 |title=Zach Bryan ‘Drunkenly’ Expresses Preference for Kanye West Over Taylor Swift, Then Apologizes and Deactivates X Account: ‘It Came Off as Rude and Desensitized’ |url=https://variety.com/2024/music/news/zach-bryan-tweet-taylor-swift-kanye-west-apologizes-deletes-account-1236149643/ |access-date=2024-09-20 |website=Variety |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-09-19 |title=Zach Bryan blames it on the alcohol after 'stupid' Kanye West-Taylor Swift tweet catches heat |url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/music/story/2024-09-19/zach-bryan-apologizes-kanye-west-taylor-swift-tweet |access-date=2024-09-20 |website=Los Angeles Times |language=en-US}}</ref>
